title: 'Nonsense' talk of war with Spain is slammed as Theresa May promises no fight over Gibraltar
text:
News 'Nonsense' talk of war with Spain is slammed as Theresa May promises no fight over Gibraltar The Government is trying to hide its failure to include a firm commitment to Gibraltar in its Article 50 letter, says MP Kevan Jones Share (L-R) Flags of the United Kingdom, Gibraltar and the European Union are flown at the Spain-Gibraltar border on April 3, 2017 in Gibraltar, Gibraltar (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Suggestions that the UK could get into a war with Spain over the future of Gibraltar have been described as “utter nonsense” by an MP. But North Durham MP Kevan Jones , a former Labour defence minister, said the Government had shown “incompetence” by failing to mention Gibraltar’s right to stay British in Prime Minister Theresa May’s letter to the EU triggering Article 50. 
He was speaking after former Conservative leader Michael Howard compared the dispute with Spain over Gibraltar to the dispute with Argentina over the Falklands , which led to the 1982 Falklands conflict in which 907 died. 
Mr Jones insisted: “That was said just to divert attention from the real issue, which is why the Government has dropped this clanger by not including Gibraltar in the negotiations.” 
Mrs May was forced to respond to Lord Howard’s comments by insisting there would be no war with Spain. The rock of Gibraltar (Photo: PA) 
She said “it’s definitely jaw, jaw”, as she spoke to reporters on a flight to Jordan for a three-day Middle East visit. 
This is a reference to a comment by former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan (sometimes attributed incorrectly to Winston Churchill), who said: “Jaw, jaw is better than war, war”. 
Asked if she would rule out a war with Spain, Mrs May replied: “What we are doing with all European countries in the European Union is sitting down and talking to them. Read More Brexit is not irreversible so don't let anyone tell you otherwise, says Mike Kelly 
“We are going to be talking to them about getting the best possible deal for the United Kingdom and for those countries, Spain included.” 
Although there was no reference to Spain’s claim to sovereignty in the EU’s response to the Article 50 letter, the decision to give a Madrid a specific role in deciding if a trade deal will apply to the Rock caused deep unease in Westminster. Video Loading Click
